results.snippet: MARK LEE and DR. JAN DAVIS may become the first married couple in space. The astronauts, who were assigned a year and a half ago to a -Spacelab scientific research mission scheduled for September 1992, were married about a month ago.   The National...
results.lead_paragraph: MARK LEE and DR. JAN DAVIS may become the first married couple in space. The astronauts, who were assigned a year and a half ago to a -Spacelab scientific research mission scheduled for September 1992, were married about a month ago. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is reviewing their assignment. "We have other husband-and-wife astronauts but have never assigned a married couple to the same crew," BARBARA SCHWARTZ, a NASA spokeswoman, said yesterday. Mr. Lee, 38, is an an Air Force lieutenant colonel who made his first shuttle flight in 1989. He is to serve as payload commander for the joint Japanese-American mission aboard the new shuttle Endeavor.It would be the first shuttle flight for Dr. Davis, 37, an engineer who became an astronaut two and a half years ago.

results.snippet: New Government efforts to refocus the space program are rippling through the aerospace industry. While they are brightening the prospects for makers of unmanned rockets, the evolving changes are clouding the future for building space shuttles and...
results.lead_paragraph: New Government efforts to refocus the space program are rippling through the aerospace industry. While they are brightening the prospects for makers of unmanned rockets, the evolving changes are clouding the future for building space shuttles and forcing a scaling back of other programs like a space station. After years of confusion about the nation's space policies, industry executives are increasingly heartened by what they see as a more coherent and realistic approach by the Administration and Congress to designing and financing space projects.

results.snippet: The Rev. JESSE JACKSON has become the second living American to be honored with a likeness of himself in a Postal Service pictorial cancellation. He is one of a group of famous black Americans pictured.   Mr. Jackson was honored Monday at Postal...
results.lead_paragraph: The Rev. JESSE JACKSON has become the second living American to be honored with a likeness of himself in a Postal Service pictorial cancellation. He is one of a group of famous black Americans pictured. Mr. Jackson was honored Monday at Postal Service ceremonies in Indianapolis. The cancellation, part of the city's celebration of Black History Month, is available only at post offices in Indianapolis. The cancellation mark also includes likenesses of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Sojourner Truth and Harriet Tubman. Postal Service officials said Mr. Jackson, whose father was a postal employee in Greenville, S.C., is the second living American to be so honored. The other was JOHN GLENN , the former astronaut who is a Senator from Ohio. (AP)
